data.title: 2.2-alpha android export apk excludes armeabi native platform in favor of armeabi-v7a
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Xubuntu 14.04 64-bit, Godot 2.2-alpha vs Godot 2.1-stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
It looks like native platform for apk exported from 2.2-alpha is set to armeabi-v7 and armeabi platform is ignored, resulting in excluding some of the android devices from supported list in Google Dev Console.

As much as adding 64-bit platform is a very good move, letting the older platforms still be available by default (if possible), or via menu settings in 'Android Export' would be a better option imho.
Let the user decide if he wants armeabi-v7 or armeabi.

data.title: High speed physics2d collision - intermittent tunneling
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot - 2.1 / windows 7

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
2d Rigid body passes through kinematic & static body when moving at high speeds (velocity around 800,1000). The tunneling happens in about 25% of the collisions with the kinematic body and about 10% collisions with the static body. Seems to happen more frequently at higher speeds. The problem persists even when setting continuous Cd to: cast shape or cast ray.

Expected: 2d rigid body should always collide and bounce off kinematic bodies and static bodies.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Surround viewport with 4 rectangle static bodies to act as walls.
create static body with circular collision shape
create kinematic body with polygon collision shape using solid-vector polygon
Set gravity in project settings to 0
Set static body to 0 friction and 1 bounce
set static body to velocity (800,1000) or higher 
control kinematic body to hit the "ball" (left & right arrow keys - optional)
After some time the "ball" will pass through the kinematic body or the wall. 

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/12995630/pong.zip

data.title: Export texture conversion done in-place so the editor is affected
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Win 10 x64, last master

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When exporting the game to `.zip`, `.pck` or `.exe` for Windows (at least), textures set to be compressed for VRAM are converted in-place. For instance, after export an uncompressed texture will be reported in the resource preview as being BC3-compressed. Loading the project again makes the original resource, with its original storage settings, to be reloaded,
I have not been able to reproduce the problem on Android export. Other platforms untested.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a project with an empty scene.
2. Add some image.
3. Set it to be compressed for VRAM on export.
4. Open the image in the resource previewer and witness its storage/compression settings.
5. Export the project for Windows.
6. Hit back and then forward on the resource preview to refresh the texture information. Now it will tell it's compressed as BC3 (or some other VRAM format).
Bonus:
7. Reload the scene or if needed quit to the project list and reopen it and check it again. Now it's back to normal.

data.title: Respect texture .flags files on export
data.body:
**_The problem_**

Textures kept as **.png** in the project can have several flags set, stored in an associated `.png.flags` file. Any texture of this kind which is set to be converted on export will get saved onto a `.tex` file. The `.png.flags` file, although bundled, is ignored because it cannot be matched any longer with the image file name. *

**_What this PR does_**

With this PR merged, the export process reads the flags from the `.png.flags` files and sets the corresponding ones in the `.tex` file.

Moreover, the flags file is read on every export and considered for the computation of the hash of the converted file. That way should those flags change from export to export, Godot is aware and knows it has to reconvert them

(*) It would be nice also to prevent these no longer needed flag files from getting into the exported game (work for another PR). Another option would have been to rename or remap these (`.png.flags` -> `.tex.flags`) but as long as the `.tex` format is capable of storing flags I believed that should be the way to go.

data.title: Crash on attempt to edit SoundPlayer2D with broken dependencies
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
linux debian stable ( 8 ) x64; ( note: not using pulseaudio )
godot 2.1 stable official

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Godot crashed several times after pressing the 'edit' arrow button on "Samples" property of SoundPlayer2D.

**Steps to reproduce:**
-Create a main level scene
-Create a 'prefab' scene with SoundPlayer2D node in it
-Create new Samples for SoundPlayer2D, save it as a .tres resource
-Import samples, add it to newly created Samples resource
-Make sure that 'prefab' is instanced within level scene
-Save everything, close the project ( exit to the project list )
-Remove samples from directory ( yes, by hand - just shift-delete .smp folks )
-Open project for editing
-Open 'prefab' scene, see the 'broken dependencies' warning
-Try to edit SoundPlayer2D "Samples" property by clicking 'edit' arrow icon.
-Experience the crash.

When Godot engine is launched from the console, I can see the following:

```
ERROR: load_interactive: Condition ' err!=OK ' is true. returned: Ref<ResourceInteractiveLoader>()
   At: core/io/resource_format_binary.cpp:1081.
ERROR: load: Failed loading resource: res://sfx/platform_move.smp
   At: core/io/resource_loader.cpp:218.
ERROR: load_interactive: Condition ' err!=OK ' is true. returned: Ref<ResourceInteractiveLoader>()
   At: core/io/resource_format_binary.cpp:1081.
ERROR: load: Failed loading resource: res://sfx/platform_move.smp
   At: core/io/resource_loader.cpp:218.
WARNING: _parse_ext_resource: Couldn't load external resource: res://sfx/platform_move.smp
   At: scene/resources/scene_format_text.cpp:122.
```

data.title: Show how many hours you have been working on a project
data.body:
I think that it would be an interesting feature to display somewhere how many hours you have been working on a project. Although non-essential, it would be cool to say, "After 2 years of working on this game, I have put in 4,000 hours into it."

Of course this wouldn't track times in other programs, but it could just track how much time you have the editor open in a project.

data.title: Fix possible buffer overflow in NetworkedMultiplayerENet
data.body: `NetworkedMultiplayerENet::get_packet()` was reporting the wrong size for the packet buffer exposing a potential buffer overflow in case of malformed/malicious packets.

data.title: Use 2 different ENet channels for reliable/unreliable packets
data.body:
This avoids stalling other sequenced but unreliable packets
(i.e. UNRELIABLE_ORDERED) when sending RELIABLE packets.
## Important Notes:

With ENet, every packet can be:
Reliable/Unreliable (will be resent or not)
Sequenced/Unsequenced (order will be enforced, or not)

A **reliable** (RS) packet MUST be sequenced, will **stall other sequenced packet** on the same channel.
An **unreliable but sequenced** (US) packet will always be **delivered in order** (if delivered at all). **Will be stalled** by undelivered reliable packets on the same channel.
An **unreliable and unsequenced** (UU) packet **will not be stalled** by other packets.

With this patch reliable and unreliable packets will use two different channels yay!

Since all unreliable-but-sequenced (US) packets will always share the same channel (and thus sequencing) out-of-order packets will be dropped even if they reference different rpc calls.

```
eg:
RECV: 1-"set_pos", // GOOD
RECV: 3-"set_pos", // GOOD
RECV: 2-"set_vel" // DROPPED
```

This will force people that want to optimize latency to implement their own timing over unreliable-and-unsequenced (UU) packets.

**I still strongly reccomend allowing the developers to select the channel when sending RPCs.**

data.title: Connecting a signal to a non-existent/not-creatable function should not be allowed
data.body:
Tested on Godot 2.1, Windows 10 64 bits

Repro:
1) Create a Button
2) Open the Node panel and double-click on the `pressed` signal to connect it
3) A window opens showing that the signal will be connected to an existing or generated function
4) Press Connect, observe the node now has a connection to a function that doesn't exists (no script was ever added). There are no error or warning in any place. Running the scene produces an error when you click the button.

This should not be allowed, or at least trigger a warning.

Edit: closing the editor after this apparently produces a freeze instead. However I couldn't reproduce it so far.

Edit 2:
the repro steps lead to a non-working connection, even if a script is added afterwards with the correct function. In TSCN it looks like this:
`[connection signal="body_enter" from="Enemy" to="." method="_on_Enemy_body_enter"]`
Disconnecting and reconnecting again fixes it, and changes the TSCN to:
`[connection signal="body_enter" from="Enemy" to="Enemy" method="_on_Enemy_body_enter"]`

data.title: sub window focus and autoswitching is confusing
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
linux ubuntu 16.04.1 lts 64 bit running mate wm (not ubuntu wm)
v2.1.stable.official

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
the relationship among the sub-windows is confusing.

it sorta makes sense to me that when i switch to a different scene tab, the central editor window changes to whatever i was last working on the scene, ok.

but the reverse doesn't happen: if i use the left/right arrows of the central editor pane to go back through history of scripts i've been editing, it doesn't change the scene tab, and it doesn't change the tree.

which means i can easily get confused/worried/lost about "wait am i editing the right file? i thought i'd created this file in another scene?!" etc.

data.title: default app gui color scheme is opposite what it should be if you ask me
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
win 7 32bit pro
godot 2.1
desktop
(also, same thing for linux ubuntu 64 bit laptop)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
The color scheme is darker than the default on most machines. E.g. browsers start off with a white page background with black text by default. (a) If I like white then Godot is different and that is annoying. (b) if I use a screen color inverter (which i do) to make most everything become darker, so that the browser pages are now white text on black background, then Godot is now bright which is annoying. In other words if an app has a different default color relationship of fg + bg vs. the standards (which in this day and age means whatever web browsers do by default) i think it is not good ux. (i mean same goes for lightroom or whatever else.)

note that (depending on what system was used to invert system colors) things sometimes get worse because of Godot's cross platform nature, is my guess: the I-bar text caret mouse cursor doesn't get the color changed for some reason so then i end up with a white on white mouse cursor in the text editor! but the arrow mouse cursor does get inverted properly. etc. etc. etc.

(thanks for a great fun program.)

data.title: Improvements on the High-Level Multiplayer API
data.body:
# Motivation

The current multiplayer API is very promising, and easy to use. There are though, in my opinion, 2 limitations:
- It does not allow to optimize the network usage by not exposing multiple **ENet channels** (see http://enet.bespin.org/Features.html#Channels )
- It does not allow to test both client and server in the same instance.

I'm opening this issue since I'd like some **feedback** from the community and the developers regarding the new features and the design.
# Proposal

My proposal is composed by two parts:
## Expose channels

Reserve the 2 channels already in use by Godot and allow to specify the number of custom channels to be used in `create_server` and `create_client` (minimum 1)
- All calls to `put_packet(packet,len)` will send the packet to the first custom channel
- SceneTree will call `put_packet(packet,len,CHANNEL)` (where CHANNEL is currently 0 and is reserved)
- From GDScript `put_packet_channel(packet,channel)` will be available in order to send the packet on `channel + first_custom_channel`
- SceneTree will emit `network_peer_packet(sender:int,channel:int,packet:RAW_ARRAY)` when receiving a packet on a custom channel. In this case `channel` will be `actual_channel - first_custom_channel`

(I have this partially implemented already in a private repo, I'm still cleaning up the code. See note 1 for a more detailed description)

This will keep the compatiblity with the current system, it will still not allow to test multiple clients on the same scene, but will enable the user to have multiple channels available for any custom data he'd like to send.

This brings us to the second proposal.
## Expose Poll and create NetworkedMultiplayerNode
- Shuoldn't we expose the `poll()` method of `NetworkedMultiplayerENet` to GDScript?
- Create a `NetworkedMultiplayerNode` that mimics the current behaviour of `SceneTree` concerning polling and handling network signals (including the new `network_peer_packet`)
- Possibly expand the node behaviour also to mimic the scene synchronizations with relative node paths (probably a long shot).

---
# Notes
## Note 1 - Details of phase one
- Add `RESERVED_CHANNELS` pre-compiler define to `NetworkedMultiplayerPeer` (the first reserved channel, that is also the number of reserved channels)
- Add function `put_packet(packet,len,channel)` to `NetworkedMultiplayerPeer`
- Override `put_packet(packet,len)` with a call to `put_packet(packet,len,RESERVED_CHANNELS)` in `NetworkedMultiplayerENet` (so default GDScript binding will send the packet on the first custom channel)
- Add function `get_packet_channel()` to `NetworkedMultiplayerPeer` (it works, like `get_sender`, on the next incoming packet)
- Update `SceneTree` to use `put_packet(packet,len,0)` (0 is the channelID already in use)
- Update `SceneTree` to emit signal `network_peer_packet(sender:int,channel:int,packet:RAW_ARRAY)` packets on `channel >= RESERVED_CHANNELS`
- Add function `put_packet_channel(packet, channel)` to `NetworkedMultiplayerENet` GDScript binding (the default `put_packet(packet)` will send the packet on the first not reserved channel) \
  Note: All GDScript references to `channel` will be considered as `channel + RESERVED_CHANNELS`
## Note 2

Example to test udp network code stability locally with iptables (20% packet loss simulated).

```
iptables -A INPUT -p udp --sport SERVER_PORT -m statistic --mode random --probability 0.2 -j DROP
iptables -A INPUT -p udp --dport SERVER_PORT -m statistic --mode random --probability 0.2 -j DROP
```

data.title: Astar node id to be a string or variant
data.body: Pretty straight forward. It could mesh better with other utilities if the id wasn't required to be an integer.

data.title: Add inline ColorPicker to Script text editor.
data.body:
Adds an option to the script editor context menu that lets you open
a ColorPicker in order to easily edit `Color()` constructors.
To do this, right click on the word `Color` and select `Pick Color`.

A side effect of this change is that the script editor now has its own
context menu instead of re-using the one from TextEdit.
It's now possible to indent left/right and to toggle comments via this menu.
I also felt free to make it more context-sensitive than before:
Now "Cut" and "Copy" will only be shown if text has actually been selected.

I also added default shortcuts for indent left/right. (alt + left/right)

Closes #6232

![picker3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8281916/18944578/8ec23a08-8626-11e6-8ebc-dcfda4c2ecf8.gif)

data.title: More obvious way to rotate GridMap tiles
data.body:
Ubuntu Studio Godot 2.1

I work with 3D procedural world, and actually, for a wall for exemple I must had 4 Tiles (North, East, West, South) Oriented tiles for make Library mesh. after that I can put on gridmap my tiles with set_cell_item(x,y,z,0), but when done, It's not possible to change Y axis of my tiles by code. I think, and I'm not alone, set_cell_item_rotation(x,y,z) function has very welcome for do that, simply for have only one tile for wall not four !
Thank you for had this: 3D projects really need rotating(x,y,z) tiles in gridmap. 

You can find my project here : https://www.facebook.com/groups/168800120225984

data.title: yield's idle_frame may confuse new people
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
2.1 latest
- Create a new scene
- Add a RichTextLabel with a lot of text (so it shows the scrollbar)
- Attach a script to it, use the code below

```
extends RichTextLabel
func _ready():
    print(get_v_scroll().is_visible())
```

It will show **false**. You might be wondering, why in the world?

Well, the reason is somehow you need to have a random `yield(get_tree(), "idle_frame")` right before printing.  Like so:

```
extends RichTextLabel
func _ready():
    yield(get_tree(), "idle_frame")
    print(get_v_scroll().is_visible())
```

My suggestion is.. can't this `yield(get_tree(), "idle_frame")` be done behind the scenes for us? And can also give us the option to use it when we need? I know it advances towards the next frame and yields for it: http://docs.godotengine.org/en/latest/reference/gdscript.html#coroutines-signals

But for newer people, and I can contest to this.. I was stuck developing a user interface for my fairly large game now for hours trying to figure out why some ui elements weren't working. And then I suddenly added  the `idle_frame` yield at the top of whatever code and it worked miraculously.

There was also another instance earlier where I was tweening a RichTextLabel and it had a weird blink for the first 0.5ms of the transition then any other new tweens / messages were fine. I spent almost an hour looking at what it could be. It turned out I just needed a `idle_frame` yield right before it.  

Yeah, I understand the need for it and I like it. But I feel like if we could somehow get it to work behind the scenes for most basic stuff (like my example code above), newer people won't have problems with it.  Especially when developing rich user interfaces. Maybe we should add somewhere in the docs that `idle_frame` is your best friend? :)  Especially when working with UI elements.

Edit: The point I am getting at is really about the example code above. If I were brand new, I would have absolutely no idea that I would need a `idle_frame` yield there. I just don't want other new people to share this fate. I would have most likely made a bug issue about it, and waste the time of other developers.

data.title: Windows: prevent huge prints from crashing the engine
data.body:
This snippet makes the engine crash on windows:

``` gdscript
func _ready():
    var dic = {}
    for y in range(0, 40):
        for x in range(0, 40):
            dic[Vector2(x,y)] = randi()%10
    print(dic)
```

It was caused by an out-of-bound access of a fixed-size buffer, which is later used for widechar conversion.
vsnprintf can actually return values greater than the provided length, as a count, even if it doesn't writes all the characters: http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/cstdio/vsnprintf/

Obviously the data is too big, but it should not make the engine crash.
This fix only prevents the crash to happen. It would also be nice to add a warning to the user.

On Unix there is nothing of this and vfprintf is used directly, I wonder why is there such a difference?
